cognitiveDistortions.name: All-or-Nothing Thinking
cognitiveDistortions.description: Seeing things in black-and-white categories

examples.text: I made one mistake in my presentation, so I'm a complete failure.
If I can't get an A in every subject, I'm worthless as a student.
Either I find the perfect relationship, or I'll be miserable forever.
If I can't stick to my diet perfectly, I might as well give up completely.
Since I couldn't save as much money as I planned, I'm terrible with finances.
My child got a B on their test. I must be a terrible parent.
If my business isn't an immediate success, it means I'm not cut out to be an entrepreneur.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Overgeneralization
cognitiveDistortions.description: Viewing a negative event as a never-ending pattern of defeat

examples.text: Nobody ever wants to spend time with me. I'll always be alone.
Every time I try something new, it ends in disaster.
I got rejected from one job interview. I'll never find employment.
My last relationship ended badly. All my relationships are doomed to fail.
I missed one workout. My fitness goals are completely ruined now.
My investment lost money. I should never invest in anything again.
One person criticized my art. I'll never be good enough to be a real artist.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Mental Filter
cognitiveDistortions.description: Dwelling on negatives and ignoring positives

examples.text: My supervisor gave me positive feedback on my project, but mentioned one area for improvement. Clearly, my work isn't good enough.
Everyone complimented my cooking, but one person didn't finish their plate. I must be terrible at cooking.
I got all As and one B, but that B proves I'm not smart enough.
My partner does so many thoughtful things, but they forgot our monthly anniversary once, so they don't really care.
I've lost weight and feel healthier, but I still can't fit into that one pair of jeans, so nothing has really changed.
My children are healthy and happy, but one of them is struggling in math, so I've failed as a parent.
My savings have grown significantly, but I made one bad investment, so I'm terrible with money.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Discounting the Positive
cognitiveDistortions.description: Rejecting positive experiences

examples.text: I only got promoted because they needed someone quickly, not because I deserved it.
They're only being nice to me because they feel sorry for me.
My weight loss is just luck, not because of my hard work and dedication.
Anyone could have gotten that scholarship, it's not really an achievement.
My successful business is just because of good timing, not my skills.
My children's good behavior is just their natural temperament, not my parenting.
The fact that I've saved a good amount for retirement is just because I'm lucky with my job, not because of good financial planning.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Jumping to Conclusions
cognitiveDistortions.description: Making negative interpretations without evidence

examples.text: My friend hasn't responded to my message for an hour. They must be angry with me.
The meeting was rescheduled. I bet they're planning to fire me.
My doctor wants to run some routine tests. It must be something serious.
The professor asked to speak with me after class. I must have failed the course.
My partner is working late again. They must be having an affair.
The stock market dropped slightly. My retirement savings are going to be wiped out.
My teenager didn't tell me about their day. They must be hiding something terrible.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Magnification or Minimization
cognitiveDistortions.description: Exaggerating negatives or downplaying positives

examples.text: I made a small error in the report. This will ruin my entire career.
I got an A- instead of an A+. My GPA is ruined forever.
I gained one pound this week. All my months of exercise were worthless.
We had one argument. Our entire relationship is falling apart.
I spent $10 over my budget. I'll never achieve financial stability.
My child got a bad grade on one quiz. Their entire academic future is ruined.
I felt awkward at one social event. I'm completely socially incompetent.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Emotional Reasoning
cognitiveDistortions.description: Believing something is true because it feels true

examples.text: I feel stupid, so I must be incompetent at my job.
I feel lonely, so nobody must care about me.
I feel like a burden, so my family would be better off without me.
I feel anxious about my health, so something must be seriously wrong.
I feel overwhelmed by my coursework, so I must not be cut out for college.
I feel nervous about my investments, so they must be too risky.
I feel insecure in my relationship, so my partner must not love me anymore.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Should Statements
cognitiveDistortions.description: Having rigid rules about how things should be

examples.text: I should never make mistakes at work.
I should always be available when friends need me.
My children should always get straight As.
I should be able to exercise every single day without fail.
I should have figured out my career path by now.
I should have started saving for retirement in my twenties.
My relationship should be perfect all the time.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Labeling
cognitiveDistortions.description: Attaching global negative labels to yourself or others

examples.text: I made a mistake on this project, I'm a total failure.
They forgot my birthday, they're a terrible friend.
I couldn't stick to my diet today, I'm completely worthless.
I failed this test, I'm just stupid.
My business venture failed, I'm a loser.
I'm in debt, I'm a financial disaster.
Our marriage ended, I'm unlovable.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Personalization
cognitiveDistortions.description: Taking responsibility for events outside your control

examples.text: My team lost the game because I missed that shot.
My friend's bad mood is because I said something wrong.
The project failed because I wasn't good enough to lead it.
My child's poor grades are because I'm a bad parent.
The company's financial problems are all my fault.
My partner's stress is because I'm not supportive enough.
The family's financial struggles are because I didn't earn enough.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Mind Reading
cognitiveDistortions.description: Assuming you know what others are thinking

examples.text: They're all thinking I'm not qualified for this job.
My friends are just pretending to like me.
The professor thinks I'm not smart enough for this course.
My partner is thinking about leaving me.
The doctor thinks I'm exaggerating my symptoms.
My children think I'm a terrible parent.
The financial advisor thinks I'm irresponsible with money.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Fortune Telling
cognitiveDistortions.description: Predicting negative outcomes without evidence

examples.text: I'll definitely fail this interview.
I'll never make any real friends here.
My health will never improve.
I'll never be able to pay off my student loans.
My relationship is doomed to fail.
My business will never succeed.
My children will never be happy in life.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Catastrophizing
cognitiveDistortions.description: Expecting the worst-case scenario to happen

examples.text: If I make a mistake in this presentation, I'll get fired and never find another job.
If I don't get into this college, my life will be ruined forever.
If I get sick, it will definitely be something terminal.
If we have one argument, our relationship will end in disaster.
If I lose this job, I'll end up homeless.
If my child fails this test, they'll never get into college and their future will be ruined.
If I say something awkward at this party, everyone will hate me forever.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Control Fallacies
cognitiveDistortions.description: Believing you have no control over your life or that you must control everything

examples.text: I have no control over my career success, it's all up to luck.
I must control every aspect of my children's lives to keep them safe.
My happiness is completely dependent on other people's actions.
I have to micromanage every detail of this project or it will fail.
My health is completely out of my control, no matter what I do.
I must control every aspect of my finances or I'll end up broke.
If I don't control every aspect of my relationship, it will fall apart.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Fallacy of Fairness
cognitiveDistortions.description: Believing that life should be fair and getting upset when it isn't

examples.text: It's not fair that they got promoted instead of me, I worked harder.
It's not fair that I have to work while others get to relax.
It's not fair that I have to deal with this health issue while others are healthy.
It's not fair that my partner has an easier job than me.
It's not fair that I have to pay more taxes than others.
It's not fair that my child has to work harder than their classmates.
It's not fair that I have to deal with this problem while others don't.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Blaming
cognitiveDistortions.description: Holding others responsible for your pain or taking responsibility for others' pain

examples.text: My career would be better if my boss wasn't so incompetent.
I wouldn't be so stressed if my partner helped more around the house.
My health problems are all because of my parents' bad genes.
My financial problems are because the economy is terrible.
My child's behavior problems are because of their friends' influence.
I'm unhappy because my friends never include me in their plans.
My academic struggles are because the teachers don't explain things well.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Heaven's Reward Fallacy
cognitiveDistortions.description: Expecting sacrifice and self-denial to pay off as if someone is keeping score

examples.text: I work so hard, I deserve to be promoted.
I've been so good with my diet, I should be able to eat whatever I want now.
I've sacrificed so much for my family, they owe me respect.
I've saved so much money, I deserve to splurge now.
I've been so supportive of my partner, they should do what I want.
I've studied so hard, I should get an A without even trying.
I've been so nice to everyone, they should all like me.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Always Being Right
cognitiveDistortions.description: Being wrong is unthinkable, going to great lengths to prove you're right

examples.text: I know I'm right about this work issue, even if the data says otherwise.
My way of parenting is the only correct way, despite what experts say.
I know more about my health than the doctors do.
My financial advice is always right, even when proven wrong.
I'm always right in arguments with my partner.
My interpretation of the research is the only valid one.
I know what's best for my friends, even when they disagree.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Fallacy of Change
cognitiveDistortions.description: Expecting others to change to suit your needs

examples.text: If my partner would just change their habits, our relationship would be perfect.
If my boss would just be more understanding, work would be great.
If my friends would just be more supportive, I'd be happier.
If my children would just behave better, parenting would be easy.
If my doctor would just listen better, my health would improve.
If my financial advisor would just make better decisions, I'd be wealthy.
If my teachers would just explain things better, I'd get better grades.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Global Labeling
cognitiveDistortions.description: Using extreme labels to describe yourself or others

examples.text: I'm a complete failure at everything I do.
My boss is absolutely terrible at managing people.
My partner is completely selfish and never thinks of others.
My child is totally irresponsible and will never learn.
I'm completely hopeless with money.
My health is completely ruined forever.
I'm absolutely terrible at making friends.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Filtering
cognitiveDistortions.description: Focusing exclusively on certain types of evidence while ignoring others

examples.text: I only remember the times I failed, not the times I succeeded.
I only notice when my partner doesn't help, not when they do.
I only focus on the negative feedback, ignoring all the positive comments.
I only remember the times my child misbehaved, not their good behavior.
I only notice when my health is bad, not when it's good.
I only focus on my financial mistakes, not my successes.
I only remember the times I felt awkward, not the times I felt confident.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Polarized Thinking
cognitiveDistortions.description: Viewing things as either perfect or a failure, with no middle ground

examples.text: If I'm not the best at my job, I'm the worst.
If my relationship isn't perfect, it's a complete disaster.
If I'm not completely healthy, I'm completely sick.
If my child isn't perfect, they're a complete failure.
If I'm not rich, I'm poor.
If I'm not popular, I'm a social outcast.
If I'm not getting straight As, I'm failing.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Overgeneralization
cognitiveDistortions.description: Making broad interpretations from a single event

examples.text: I failed one test, so I'll fail all my classes.
One person didn't like my idea, so no one will.
My partner forgot one thing, so they never remember anything.
My child misbehaved once, so they're always misbehaving.
I made one bad investment, so I'm terrible with money.
I felt awkward at one party, so I'm always awkward.
I had one bad health day, so my health is always bad.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Mind Reading
cognitiveDistortions.description: Assuming you know what others are thinking without evidence

examples.text: My boss didn't smile at me, so they must be angry with me.
My friend didn't text back, so they must not care about me.
My partner is quiet, so they must be upset with me.
My child didn't want to talk, so they must be hiding something.
The doctor ordered tests, so they must think I'm seriously ill.
The financial advisor suggested changes, so they must think I'm irresponsible.
The professor asked questions, so they must think I'm not smart enough.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Emotional Reasoning
cognitiveDistortions.description: Believing that because you feel something, it must be true

examples.text: I feel anxious about my presentation, so it must be going badly.
I feel guilty about spending money, so I must be irresponsible.
I feel sad about my relationship, so it must be failing.
I feel overwhelmed by parenting, so I must be a bad parent.
I feel tired, so I must be getting sick.
I feel nervous at parties, so I must be socially awkward.
I feel confused in class, so I must not be smart enough.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Should Statements
cognitiveDistortions.description: Using 'should' statements to criticize yourself or others

examples.text: I should be able to handle this workload without stress.
I should be able to save more money than I do.
I should be a better partner than I am.
I should be able to parent without making mistakes.
I should be able to maintain perfect health.
I should be more outgoing at social events.
I should be able to understand everything in class immediately.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Personalization
cognitiveDistortions.description: Taking responsibility for events outside your control

examples.text: The project failed because of me.
My friend's bad mood is because of something I did.
My partner's stress is because I'm not supportive enough.
My child's struggles are because I'm a bad parent.
My health problems are because I didn't take care of myself.
My financial problems are because I'm irresponsible.
My academic struggles are because I'm not smart enough.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Fallacy of Change
cognitiveDistortions.description: Expecting others to change to suit your needs

examples.text: If my boss would just change their management style, work would be perfect.
If my partner would just change their habits, our relationship would be great.
If my friends would just change their interests, we'd get along better.
If my child would just change their behavior, parenting would be easy.
If my doctor would just change their approach, my health would improve.
If my financial advisor would just change their strategy, I'd be wealthy.
If my teachers would just change their teaching style, I'd learn better.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Global Labeling
cognitiveDistortions.description: Using extreme labels to describe yourself or others

examples.text: I'm a complete failure at everything.
My boss is absolutely terrible at everything.
My partner is completely selfish in every way.
My child is totally irresponsible in everything they do.
I'm completely hopeless with all financial matters.
My health is completely ruined in every aspect.
I'm absolutely terrible at all social interactions.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Filtering
cognitiveDistortions.description: Focusing exclusively on certain types of evidence while ignoring others

examples.text: I only remember my failures, not my successes.
I only notice when my partner doesn't help, not when they do.
I only focus on the negative feedback, ignoring all the positive comments.
I only remember the times my child misbehaved, not their good behavior.
I only notice when my health is bad, not when it's good.
I only focus on my financial mistakes, not my successes.
I only remember the times I felt awkward, not the times I felt confident.

cognitiveDistortions.description: Viewing things as either perfect or a failure, with no middle ground

examples.text: If I'm not the best at my job, I'm the worst.
If my relationship isn't perfect, it's a complete disaster.
If I'm not completely healthy, I'm completely sick.
If my child isn't perfect, they're a complete failure.
If I'm not rich, I'm poor.
If I'm not popular, I'm a social outcast.
If I'm not getting straight As, I'm failing.

One person didn't like my idea, so no one will.
My partner forgot one thing, so they never remember anything.
My child misbehaved once, so they're always misbehaving.
I made one bad investment, so I'm terrible with money.
I felt awkward at one party, so I'm always awkward.
I had one bad health day, so my health is always bad.

examples.text: My boss didn't smile at me, so they must be angry with me.
My friend didn't text back, so they must not care about me.

I feel sad about my relationship, so it must be failing.
I feel overwhelmed by parenting, so I must be a bad parent.

I should be able to save more money than I do.

I should be able to parent without making mistakes.
I should be able to maintain perfect health.

My friend's bad mood is because of something I did.
My partner's stress is because I'm not supportive enough.
My child's struggles are because I'm a bad parent.
My health problems are because I didn't take care of myself.
My financial problems are because I'm irresponsible.
My academic struggles are because I'm not smart enough.

cognitiveDistortions.description: Expecting others to change to suit your needs

examples.text: If my boss would just change their management style, work would be perfect.
If my partner would just change their habits, our relationship would be great.
If my friends would just change their interests, we'd get along better.
If my child would just change their behavior, parenting would be easy.
If my doctor would just change their approach, my health would improve.
If my financial advisor would just change their strategy, I'd be wealthy.

examples.text: I'm a complete failure at everything.
My boss is absolutely terrible at everything.
My partner is completely selfish in every way.
My child is totally irresponsible in everything they do.
I'm completely hopeless with all financial matters.
My health is completely ruined in every aspect.
I'm absolutely terrible at all social interactions.

examples.text: I only remember my failures, not my successes.
I only notice when my partner doesn't help, not when they do.
I only focus on the negative feedback, ignoring all the positive comments.
I only remember the times my child misbehaved, not their good behavior.
I only notice when my health is bad, not when it's good.
I only focus on my financial mistakes, not my successes.
I only remember the times I felt awkward, not the times I felt confident.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Polarized Thinking
cognitiveDistortions.description: Viewing things as either perfect or a failure, with no middle ground

examples.text: If I'm not the best at my job, I'm the worst.
If my relationship isn't perfect, it's a complete disaster.
If I'm not completely healthy, I'm completely sick.
If my child isn't perfect, they're a complete failure.
If I'm not rich, I'm poor.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Overgeneralization
cognitiveDistortions.description: Making broad interpretations from a single event

examples.text: I failed one test, so I'll fail all my classes.
One person didn't like my idea, so no one will.
My partner forgot one thing, so they never remember anything.
My child misbehaved once, so they're always misbehaving.
I made one bad investment, so I'm terrible with money.
I felt awkward at one party, so I'm always awkward.
I had one bad health day, so my health is always bad.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Mind Reading
cognitiveDistortions.description: Assuming you know what others are thinking without evidence

examples.text: My boss didn't smile at me, so they must be angry with me.
My friend didn't text back, so they must not care about me.
My partner is quiet, so they must be upset with me.
My child didn't want to talk, so they must be hiding something.
The doctor ordered tests, so they must think I'm seriously ill.
The financial advisor suggested changes, so they must think I'm irresponsible.
The professor asked questions, so they must think I'm not smart enough.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Fortune Telling
cognitiveDistortions.description: Predicting negative outcomes without evidence

examples.text: I'll definitely fail this interview, no matter how well I prepare.
I'll never make any real friends in this new city.
My health will never improve, no matter what I do.
I'll never be able to pay off my student loans.
My relationship is doomed to fail, no matter how hard we try.
My business will never succeed, even if I work hard.
My children will never be happy in life, no matter what I do.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Catastrophizing
cognitiveDistortions.description: Expecting the worst-case scenario to happen

examples.text: If I make a mistake in this presentation, I'll get fired and never find another job.
If I don't get into this college, my life will be ruined forever.
If I get sick, it will definitely be something terminal.
If we have one argument, our relationship will end in disaster.
If I lose this job, I'll end up homeless.
If my child fails this test, they'll never get into college and their future will be ruined.
If I say something awkward at this party, everyone will hate me forever.

cognitiveDistortions.name: Control Fallacies
cognitiveDistortions.description: Believing you have no control over your life or that you must control everything

examples.text: I have no control over my career success, it's all up to luck.
I must control every aspect of my children's lives to keep them safe.
My happiness is completely dependent on other people's actions.
I have to micromanage every detail of this project or it will fail.
My health is completely out of my control, no matter what I do.
I must control every aspect of my finances or I'll end up broke.
If I don't control every aspect of my relationship, it will fall apart.

difficulties.1: Beginner - Clear examples with obvious distortion patterns
difficulties.2: Intermediate - More subtle examples with mixed emotions
difficulties.3: Advanced - Complex situations with multiple potential distortions
difficulties.4: Expert - Nuanced examples requiring careful analysis
difficulties.5: Master - Highly complex scenarios with interrelated distortions
